Bioinformatic Resources

Below are a list of common databases and tools. This list is not exhaustive and may not be up to date. Listing of tools on this page is not an endorsement of the tool.

Databases and genome viewers

A list of useful databases and online data viewers

NCBI (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/): US sequence archive and biomedical data resource.

Education (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/education): information and documentation on using NCBI resources.

Gene (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gene): A database that aggregates information about genes.

GEO (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo): A database of functional genomics data.

Epigenomics (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/epigenomics): A collection of genomic maps of epigenetic data.

dbSNP (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/snp): A database of small scale genome variation.

dbVar (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/dbvar): A database of large scale genomic structural variation.

Genome (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genome): access to genome information

CloneDB (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/clone): A catalog of genomic and cell line based clones.

Genome Workbench (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/projects/gbench): A client side genome viewer and analyis tool.

SRA (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra): An archive of next generation sequences.

Pubmed (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed): Literature resource.

Ensembl (http://www.ensembl.org/index.html): genome databases for vertebrates and other eukaryotic species.

UCSC (http://genome.ucsc.edu/): browser for genome data of selected species.

Mouse Genome Informatics (http://www.informatics.jax.org/): Model organism database for mouse

International Gene Trap Consortium (http://www.genetrap.org/): Database of trapped genes.

International Mouse Knockout database (http://www.knockoutmouse.org/): Database of knocked out genes (includes gene traps).

Rat Genome Database (http://rgd.mcw.edu/): Model organism database for rat.

Genome Reference Consortium (http://genomereference.org): Curation of human, mouse and zebrafish reference genome assemblies.

Map Viewer: (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/mapview): Genome tool for viewing multiple coordinate systems (assemblies, maps, etc) simultaneously.

Sequence Viewer (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/projects/sviewer): A graphical view you will see on many NCBI pages. This tools allows for viewing of annotations on sequence data and provides access to some analysis tools.

Genome Workbench (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/tools/gbench): A client side tool for viewing and analyzing sequence data.

Integrated Genomics Viewer (http://www.broadinstitute.org/software/igv/): A client side tool for viewing large scale genome data.

The 1000 Genomes Browser (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/variation/tools/1000genomes

Analysis Resources

Biostar (http://biostars.org/): An online resource to ask questions about bioinformatics.

SeqAnswers (http://seqanswers.com/): An online forum for asking questions about sequencing and sequence analysis.

Galaxy (http://main.g2.bx.psu.edu/): a resource that allows you to do some bioinformatic analysis without having to learn to program.

List of public Galaxy Installations (http://wiki.galaxyproject.org/PublicGalaxyServers A list of other public Galaxy installations.

Gene Pattern (http://www.broadinstitute.org/cancer/software/genepattern/): A genomic analysis platform from the Broad Institute.

GenomeSpace (http://www.genomespace.org): A resource to allow scientists without programming skills to access genome analysis tools.

GenPlay (http://genplay.einstein.yu.edu/wiki/index.php/Main_Page): A genomic data analyzer for the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

NCBI Remap (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genome/tools/remap): A tool for projecting features from one assembly to another or from an assembly to a RefSeqGene.

liftOver (http://genome.ucsc.edu/cgi-bin/hgLiftOver): A tool for projecting features from one assembly to another.

Alignment software

This list of software contains links for well established aligners for larger sequences (typically those in GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ). There is rapid software development for Next Generation Sequencing applications, so rather than list all options, I've linked to two sites that are mainting lists of these applications.

BLAST (http://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi): a suite of alignment tools designed to align nucleotides and protein.

SPLIGN (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sutils/splign/splign.cgi): a tool specifically designed to aligned spliced sequences to genomic DNA.

BLAT (http://genome.ucsc.edu/cgi-bin/hgBlat): find regions of similiarity between closely related biological sequences (nucleotide or protein).

SeqAnswers list of NGS software ( http://seqanswers.com/forums/showthread.php?t=43)

Wikipedia list of alignment software (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_sequence_alignment_software): This pages is not limited to NGS aligners.

HTS Mappers list list of HTS mappers with feature comparisons. (http://wwwdev.ebi.ac.uk/fg/hts_mappers

Software toolkits

Software libraries for writing your own processes

SRA Toolkit (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK47540/): software for manipulating data stored in the SRA.

NCBI C++ toolkit (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK7160/): library code for managing sequencing data.

E-utilities (http://eutils.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/): modules for using Perl to query the Entrez search system.

GATK (http://www.broadinstitute.org/gsa/wiki/index.php/The_Genome_Analysis_Toolkit): toolkit for manipulating next generation sequencing data.

SAMtools (http://sourceforge.net/projects/samtools/): tools for manipulating SAM/BAM files.

VCFtools (http://vcftools.sourceforge.net/): tools for manipulating VCF.

Learn to code

Resources for learning to write your own code

Software Carpentry (http://software-carpentry.org): Introduction to many aspects of producing quality software.

Code Academy (http://www.codeacademy.com): Interactive web site that teaches you to code by coding.

Learn Python the Hard way(http://learnpythonthehardway.org): Site for learning Python.

List of courses and Tutorials(http://stephenturner.us/p/edu): A web page maintained by Stephen Turner linking to in person classes and on-line material for NGS analyis.

Scientific computing modules for Python(http://www.lowindata.com/2013/installing-scientific-python-on-mac-os-x/): A list of useful modules for scientific computing using Python and how to install them (MacOX).

On line tutorials

On-line tutorials for specific tools and applications

UC Davis RNA-Seq tutorial (http://training.bioinformatics.ucdavis.edu/docs/2012/05/RNA/index.html): An in depth guide to performing RNA-Seq analysis.
